Response.summary: The Response interface of the Fetch API represents the response to a request.

remarks.para: You can create a new Response object using the constructor, but you are more likely to encounter a Response object being returned as the result of another API operation—for example, a service worker , or a simple .

ResponseArrayBuffer.summary:
The arrayBuffer() method of the interface
takes a stream and reads it to completion. It returns a promise
that resolves with an .
ResponseArrayBuffer.returns: A promise that resolves with an .

ResponseBlob.summary:
The blob() method of the interface takes
a stream and reads it to completion. It returns a promise that
resolves with a .
ResponseBlob.returns: A promise that resolves with a .

ResponseBody.summary: The body read-only property of the interface is a of the body contents.
ResponseBody.value:
A , or else null for any Response object constructed with a null body property, or for any actual HTTP response that has no body.The stream is a readable byte stream, which supports zero-copy reading using a .
NOTECurrent browsers don't actually conform to the spec requirement to set the body property to null for responses with no body (for example, responses to HEAD requests, or 204 No Content responses).

ResponseBodyUsed.summary: The bodyUsed read-only property of the interface is a boolean value that indicates whether the body has been read yet.

ResponseBytes.summary:
The bytes() method of the interface takes a stream and reads it to completion.
It returns a promise that resolves with a .
ResponseBytes.returns: A promise that resolves with an .

ResponseClone.summary: The clone() method of the interface creates a clone of a response object, identical in every way, but stored in a different variable.

remarks.para:
Like the underlying api,
the of a cloned Response
will signal backpressure at the rate of the faster consumer of the two bodies,
and unread data is enqueued internally on the slower consumed body
without any limit or backpressure.
Backpressure refers to the mechanism by which the streaming consumer of data
(in this case, the code that reads the body)
slows down the producer of data (such as the TCP server)
so as not to load large amounts of data in memory
that is waiting to be used by the application.
If only one cloned branch is consumed, then the entire body will be buffered in memory.
Therefore, clone() is one way to read a response twice in sequence,
but you should not use it to read very large bodies
in parallel at different speeds.

clone() throws a if the response body has already been used.
In fact, the main reason clone() exists is to allow multiple uses of body objects (when they are one-use only.)

ResponseError.summary: The error() static method of the interface returns a new Response object associated with a network error.

remarks.para: This is mainly useful when writing service workers: it enables a service worker to send a response from a event handler that will cause the call in the main app code to reject the promise.
An error response has its set to error.

ResponseError.returns: A object.Suppose a web app has a service worker, which contains the following fetch event handler:With this service worker, all fetch requests from the app will pass through the service worker to the network, except for requests to fetch "salamander.jpg", which will reject. This means that the following main thread code would throw an error, and the catch handler will run.

ResponseFormData.summary:
The formData() method of the interface
takes a stream and reads it to completion. It returns a promise
that resolves with a object.

blockquote.para:
This is mainly relevant to service workers. If a user submits
a form and a service worker intercepts the request, you could for example call
formData() on it to obtain a key-value map, modify some fields, then send
the form onwards to the server (or use it locally).

ResponseFormData.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves with a object.

ResponseHeaders.summary:
The headers read-only property of the
interface contains the object associated
with the response.

ResponseJson.summary:
The json() method of the interface takes
a stream and reads it to completion. It returns a promise which
resolves with the result of parsing the body text as .

remarks.para: Note that despite the method being named json(), the result is not JSON but is instead the result of taking JSON as input and parsing it to produce a JavaScript object.

ResponseJson.returns:
A that resolves to a JavaScript object. This object could be
anything that can be represented by JSON — an object, an array, a string, a number…

ResponseJson.summary:
The json() static method of the interface returns a Response that contains the provided JSON data as body, and a Content-Type header which is set to application/json.
The response status, status message, and additional headers can also be set.

remarks.para:
The method makes it easy to create Response objects for returning JSON encoded data.
Service workers, for example, intercept fetch requests made by a browser, and might use json() to construct a Response from cached JSON data to return to the main thread.
The json() method can also be used in server code to return JSON data for single page applications, and any other applications where a JSON response is expected.

ResponseOk.summary: The ok read-only property of the interface contains a Boolean stating whether the response was successful (status in the range 200-299) or not.

ResponseRedirected.summary: The redirected read-only property of the interface indicates whether or not the response is the result of a request you made which was redirected.

blockquote.para:
Checking redirected to prevent redirects is not recommended, because by the time a response is received, the redirect has already happened, and you may have sent the request to an unintended destination, potentially sending sensitive information.
Instead, you should do the filtering when you call .
See the example Disallowing redirects, which shows this being done.

ResponseRedirected.value: A boolean value which is true if the response indicates that your request was redirected.

ResponseRedirect.summary: The redirect() static method of the interface returns a Response resulting in a redirect to the specified URL.

blockquote.para:
This can be used alongside the ServiceWorker API.
A controlling service worker could intercept a page's request and redirect it as desired.
This will actually lead to a real redirect if a service worker sends it upstream.

ResponseResponse.summary: The Response() constructor creates a new object.

ResponseStatus.summary: The status read-only property of the interface contains the HTTP status codes of the response.

remarks.para: For example, 200 for success, 404 if the resource could not be found.

ResponseStatus.value:
An unsigned short number.
This is one of the HTTP response status codes.A value is 0 is returned for a response whose is opaque, opaqueredirect, or error.

ResponseStatusText.summary: The statusText read-only property of the interface contains the status message corresponding to the HTTP status code in .

remarks.para: For example, this would be OK for a status code 200, Continue for 100, Not Found for 404.

ResponseStatusText.value:
A containing the HTTP status message associated with the response.
The default value is "".See HTTP response status codes for a list of codes and their associated status messages.
Note that HTTP/2 does not support status messages.

ResponseText.summary:
The text() method of the interface takes a stream and reads it to completion.
It returns a promise that resolves with a .
The response is always decoded using UTF-8.
ResponseText.returns: A Promise that resolves with a .

ResponseType.summary: The type read-only property of the interface contains the type of the response. The type determines whether scripts are able to access the response body and headers.
ResponseType.value: A string, which may be any of the following values:

ResponseUrl.summary:
The url read-only property of the interface contains the URL of the response.
The value of the url property will be the final URL obtained after any redirects.
